bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, February 19, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 63. Consular. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia February 19, 1901

p.add: acknowledged by form March 26, 1907 See his No 55 of Nov 7 1900 See his no 68 of May 10, 07

div1.p: Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. In relation to the death of William Porker.
No. 63. Consular Legation of the United States. Monrovia Liberia; February 19, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say acknowledge the receipt February 18, 1901, of your No. 30. Consular G. of Jan. 9, 1901, in which you acknowledge the receipt of my No. 55, Consular of Nov. 27, 1900; in which I reported the death of William Porker, an American citizen, late of Spokane, Washington. In reply to your No. 30, Consular G. I have to say, I did not forward said No. 55, Consular, as a final report relative

relative to the demise of Wm. Porker, but neither as a matter of information. Mr. Porker, an Odd Fellow died at some distance from this Consulate General, the Probate Judge of Cape Mount Territory, had appointed George H. Lewis; also an Odd Fellow, and the Sheriff of said Cape Mount Territory with whom Porker had lodged, during his short stay at Robertsport, as administrator of the effects &c. of the deceased. At the time of writing, I saw that some considerable time would necessarily, have to elapse, as will as much correspondence, before I could be pleased in a portion to submit a proper official report &c, of the demise and settlement of the said estate, Hence, my short reference to the death

death of Porker, without attempting to give particular or writing to his widow; hoping, in a very few days, to have been enabled to have given a full account of his death, effects &c. But, ever, at this writing I have to say, I have not been able to get possession of the Inventory nor effects of the deceased, from the said administrator George H. Lewis, the Sheriff of Cape Mount Territory. Hence, I did on Jan. 29, 1901, file a complaint and demand with the State Department. Monrovia: for the delivery of the said Inventory and affects by the said George H. Lewis to me.
The State Department has referred the matter to the Department of justice, and the Attorny General has written the Judge of the Probate
Probate Court for said Territory, demanding him to forward the said Inventory effects &c to me.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
